statement:
Cauchy has originally presented the multiplication rule
$$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty{a_j}\cdot\sum_{k=1}^\infty{b_k} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty(a_1b_n+a_2b_{n-1}+\ldots+a_nb_1)\end{aligned}$$
for two series. His assumption was that both of the multiplicand series
should be absolutely convergent. Mertens (1875) lightened the assumption
requiring that both multiplicands should be convergent but at least one
of them absolutely convergent (see the entry). N. H. Abel’s most general
form of the multiplication rule is the

**Theorem.** The rule (1) for multiplication of series with real or
complex terms is valid as soon as all three of its series are
convergent.\
[*Proof.*]{} We consider the corresponding power series
$$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty{a_j}x^j, \qquad \sum_{k=1}^\infty{b_k}x^k.\end{aligned}$$
When $x = 1$, they give the series
$$\sum_{j=1}^\infty{a_j}, \quad \sum_{k=1}^\infty{b_k}$$ which we assume
to converge. Thus the power series are absolutely convergent for
$|x| < 1$, whence they obey the multiplication rule due to Cauchy:
$$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty{a_j}x^j\cdot\sum_{k=1}^\infty{b_k}x^k = \sum_{n=1}^\infty(a_1b_n+a_2b_{n-1}+\ldots+a_nb_1)x^{n+1}.\end{aligned}$$
On the other hand, the sums of the power series (2) are, as is well
known, continuous functions on the interval $[0,\,1]$; the same concerns
the right hand side of (3), because for $x = 1$ it becomes the third
series which we assume convergent. When $x \to 1-$, we infer that
$$\sum_{j=1}^\infty{a_j}x^j \to \sum_{j=1}^\infty{a_j}, \qquad \sum_{k=1}^\infty{b_k}x^k \to \sum_{k=1}^\infty{b_k}$$
and that the limit of the right hand side of (3) is the right hand side
of (1). Since the equation (3) is true for $|x| < 1$, also the limits of
both of (3), as $x \to 1-$, are equal. Therefore the equation (1) is in
with the assumptions of the theorem.

[8]{} : [*Differentiali- ja integralilasku ja sen sovellutukset III.
Toinen osa.*]{} Mercatorin Kirjapaino Osakeyhtiö, Helsinki (1940).
